Ruderal Wetland
aBRFRx-y3.memHandModelNotes:
Species is non-migrant (NatureServe 2004), found in shallow waters.  Species will use disturbed (clear/cuts, utility swath) when in association with wet areas.  So model disturbed classes only when they intersect with wet vegetation or open/standing water(30m buffer). ALS Feb05

Removed hand modeling and used AMUs (clear cuts/ utility swath) with 30m buffer from PMUs. MJR 14feb07.

Species is non-migrant (NatureServe 2004), found in shallow waters.  Species will use disturbed (clear/cuts, utility swath) when in association with wet areas.  So model disturbed classes only when they intersect with wet vegetation or open/standing water(30m buffer). ALS Feb05

references.B75CON01NAUS: Conant, R. 1975. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Eastern and Central North America. Second Edition. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. xvii + 429 pp.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.A83HOF01NAUS: Hoffman, R. L. 1983. Pseudacris brimleyi. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 311.1-311.2.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.B49WRI01NAUS: Wright, A. H. and A. A. Wright. 1949. Handbook of frogs and toads of the United States and Canada. Comstock Publishing Company, Ithica, NY. 640 pp.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.A94COC01NAUS: Cocroft, R. B. 1994. A cladistic analysis of chorus frog phylogeny (Hylidae:PSEUDACRIS). Herpetologica 50:420-437.
